metadata.title: Lordosis
anatomical location body part affected: Cervical and lumbar spinal curves are convex anteriorly, or inwardly curved, due to the wedging of the vertebral bodies and intervertebral discs within the spinal column. In the lumbar spine, lordosis comprises three segments: upper (L1), middle (L2–L4),  and lower (L5). The cervical parameters are the upper (O–C2)  and lower cervical curvatures (C2–C7),  the C7 slope, the spino-cranial angle, and the vertical cervical offset
description: There is a normal degree of lordosis present in the cervical and lumbar spines. Normal curvatures of the spinal column exist to protect the spinal cord and to absorb shock during movement. They are the result of humans becoming bipedal(21)

Lordosis is considered normal. However, the term lordosis can be confusing, as some use the term to indicate pathology, usually when there is hyperlordosis.(22) For clarification, when lordosis becomes atypical, the condition is known as: –hyperlordosis – exaggerated curve –hypolordosis – decreased curve

In the lumbar spine there are many different ways to measure lordosis, depending on how many lumbar (or thoracic or sacral) vertebrae are included.Lordosis routinely is measuredradiographically.(22) One common way to measure lumbar lordosis is by the angle between the upper plane of L1 and the upper plane of S1.(23) Lumbar lordosis angles are the following: –Hyperlordosis: > 70° –Normal lordosis: 31°–50° –Hypolordosis: 11°–30° –Lumbar kyphosis: < 10°

The average cervical lordosis is 20˚ if measured by the slope of C7 as in typical radiologic methods.(21) In the cervical spine, lordosis is also commonly defined by the angle between the posterior tangents of the vertebral bodies of C2 and C7, measurement of which is known as the Harrison posterior tangent method

The amount of lordosis will vary in different conditions. Children tend to have less cervical lordosis and more lumbar lordosis compared to adolescents and adults.(22) Continuity of positional measurements should be considered with all baseline and follow-up measurements(12)

ICD-10 codes.M40.5: lordosis, unspecified (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: General symptoms –Postural deformityinhyperlordosis or hypolordosis –Neck and back pain, generally increased with prolonged sitting/standing –Radicular symptoms –Headaches –Functional limitation in more severe cases

Frequently observed postural abnormalities(24) –Hyperlordosis -Increased lumbar lordosis -Increased anterior pelvic tilt -Associated flexion of hip joints, hyperextension of knees, and plantar flexion of the ankles –Forward head posture -Head anterior to shoulders -Middle cervical spine extended -Lower cervical segments flexed -Upper cervical spine hyperextended –Kyphotic posture -Increased thoracic kyphosis -Head protraction -Flattened or reversed lower cervical lordosis -Increased upper cervical lordosis -Protraction of shoulders and scapulae –Flat back posture -Hypolordosis -Flattened lower part of thoracic kyphosis and increased kyphosis in upper part of thoracic region -Pelvis neutral or decreased anterior tilt –Swayback posture -Thoracic kyphosis extended to upper part of lumbar spine -Posterior shift of upper thoracic region -Decreased lordosis -Normal or slightly decreased anterior pelvic tilt Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: If lumbar spondylolysis or spondylolisthesis is suspected, care must be used when assessing lumbar extension or end of range hyperlordotic positions

causes: Atypical lumbar lordosis may be congenital or acquired–Congenital lumbar lordosis is due to a lack of proper development of the posterior element of the vertebral spine overmultiple vertebral levels–Acquired lumbar hyperlordosis can be due to:-hip flexion contracture(1)-anterior pelvic rotation/anteversion-severe back spasm/tightness-achondroplasia-spondylolisthesis(1)-high-heeled  shoes–Acquired lumbar hypolordosis can be due to:-posterior pelvic tilt/rotation-spinal fusion-hip extensor weakness-altered gait patterns when wearing high heels(20)
Atypical cervical hyperlordosis may result from:–neck pain–headache–spondylotic myelopathy–degenerative disorders of the disks and vertebral bodies
Atypical cervical hypolordosis may be caused by:–laminoplasty–whiplash injury
pathogenesis: Lordosis is a result of the physiological alignment of the spine, in which muscular forces are used in the most efficientmanner(21)

For acquired abnormal curvature of the spine, gradual loss of lordosis or excessive lordosis often progresses in response topain or spinal injury. Gradual tightening or spasm of musculature accompanied by strain of opposing ligaments results indeformation of the normal lordotic curve of the cervical or lumbar spine
In congenital lumbar lordosis, the posterior column fails to grow or keep up with the growth of the anterior column and adeforming lordotic curve develops(24)

Some researchers believe that the most common mechanism for a loss of lumbar lordosis is degenerative disc diseaserelated to aging. However, this is controversial, as some researchers have found no relationship between lumbardegenerative disc disease and lumbar lordosis.(2) In contrast, other researchers with the aid of CT have found an associationbetween lumbar lordosis and spinal degeneration(3)

The relationship between lordosis and low back pain (LBP) has been examined. Authors of a 2017 systematic reviewconcluded that hypolordosis is more associated with LBP than neutral of hyperlordosis(25)–The authors stated that disc herniation and degeneration were associated with hypolordosis
risk factors: Factors that generally influence lordosis in both cervical and lumbar region–Advancing age(21)–Trauma–Surgery–Muscle contracture–Increased/chronic neck or back pain–Neurological impairment
Risk factors for hypolordosis–Poor posture(24)–Poor ergonomics–Degenerative disc disease(21)
Risk factors for hyperlordosis in lumbar spine(24)–Obesity–Pregnancy–Spondylolisthesis or spondylolysis
Authors of a meta-analysis  determined that in asymptomatic individualsmales have a higher lordotic cervical curvature thanfemales(26)

overall contraindications precautions: Although excessive spinal curvature might be idiopathic, it can also be the first symptom of an underlying condition such as a neuromuscular disorder or tumor
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: If lumbar spondylolysis or spondylolisthesis is suspected, care must be used when assessing lumbar extension or end of range hyperlordotic positions

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: How long has the condition been present? Is the patient able to correct his or her posture independently?

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about patient’s past and current medical management. How has the pain responded to treatments?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what, if any, medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effectively controlling symptoms?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: X-rays  may be used to evaluate for spondylolisthesis or a vertebral fracture. Most research
uses Xrays  to measure lordotic angles
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Pain generally is increased with prolonged sitting/standing
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Patients may have neck and back pain, radicular symptoms, and/or headaches
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). In general, are the symptoms getting better, getting worse, or staying the same?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to this condition. Is the patient able to find a position of comfort?Document any use of supplemental oxygen or the need for ventilation
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note the use of supplemental oxygen, mechanical ventilator, etc. Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes___ No___ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any previous back/neck injuries or surgeries? Any radiological testing done previously?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications during pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational activities or competitive sports? Does the patient work? What does his or her job require (e.g., sitting at a computer all day, heavy lifting)? Is the patient a student sitting in class all day?  -Authors of a study in Iran found that lumbar lordosis was not significantly different between subjects with and without hamstring tightness and those with and without LBP in patients in various lifestyle/work settings (e.g., prolonged sitting vs. standing and/or walking)(14)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document use of equipment. Patients may have functional limitations in more severe cases
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Evaluate for a leg-length  discrepancy. Record height and weight in order to calculate BMI
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Evaluate need for, proper fit, and use of ambulatory assistive devices
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Assess standing static and dynamic balance, as well as sitting static and dynamic balance in more severely affected patients –Additionally, screen for proprioception deficits using the Romberg balance test. In the Romberg balance test, the patient stands with feet together and arms across the chest. Patient should be able to maintain still standing with eyes open and closed; inability to maintain stance with eyes closed indicates proprioceptive deficits
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for gait disturbances and abnormalities secondary to spinal deformity and associated muscle contractures. Assess for appropriateness of assistive devicesAssess vertebrae for hyper/hypomobility, spondylolisthesis/lysis, facet syndrome, and rotation. In some cases of spondylolisthesis, a palpable shelf or step-off  of the affected vertebrae may be present and tenderness of the spinous process above may be noted
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength of both back/neck musculature and abdominals. Also assess extremity strength as indicated
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess for atrophy of muscles that may contribute to the spinal deformity
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Perform assessment of standing, standing flexion, and sitting posture for deformity of cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine. Lumbar lordosis is greatest in standing and then decreases from supine to sitting(10) –Increased lumbar lordosis often presents with increased hollowing of the low back as well as prominence of the buttocks. In individuals with lumbar hypolordosis, compensatory knee flexion might be observed –Pelvic posture can also influence lumbar lordosis, with an increase in lordosis with an anterior tilt and vice versa.(24) Changes in lumbar lordosis will often be found with scoliosis(4)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess for loss of spinal active range of motion (AROM) and passive range of motion (PROM). Assess flexibility of muscles that may contribute to the spinal deformity (e.g., hip flexor tightness) –Hypolordosis and reduced ROM in both the hamstrings and in trunk lateral flexion have been associated with LBP(29)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Should be normal unless there is nerve root or spinal cord compression. Assess upper extremity, abdominal, and lower extremity reflexes(4)Assess as indicated
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess for deficits with light touch, deep pressure, and two-point  discrimination
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisAlthough radiographs are the gold standard for measuring lordosis, financial cost, time, and health risks make its use for this purpose prohibitive. This technique involves the use of a flexible ruler applied over the skin of the cervical or lumbar spine. The distance between two anatomical landmarks (e.g., distance between the  spinous processes of T12 and S2) is measured, as well as the distance from the spine to the midpoint between the two anatomical landmarks. The values are then used in a formula to calculate the lordotic angle. Although some studies have demonstrated the reliability of this technique,(5,6) other studies have found itunreliable(7) -Researchers in Iran investigated lumbar lordosis changes during prone and prone lying knee flexion (PLKF) in patients with and without LBP. A flexible ruler was used to measure lumbar lordosis of all 80 subjects in each position. Statistically significant changes were identified when comparing prone position to PLKF in subjects with and without LBP, with greater changes identified in patients with LBP(11)Gravity-based  bubble inclinometers and smartphones with an inclinometer application have been shown to have good interrater and intra-rater reliability for measuring lumbar lordosis. The instruments are placed on landmarks T12-L1  and S1-S2,  with the angles from both landmarks added together to calculate the angle of lordosis(9) –Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) –Neck Disability Index (NDI) –Short Form 36 (SF-36)

cryotherapy contraindications: Cryotherapy  contraindications -Raynaud’s syndrome -Cryoglobulinemia -Cold urticaria -Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria -Impaired circulation -Over area of nerve regrowth
cryotherapy precautions: Cryotherapy  precautions -Hypertension -Hypersensitivity to cold -Over an acute wound -Over superficial nerves

Aquatic therapy  contraindications/precautions -Fear of water -Avoid warm/hot water if patient is pregnant or has multiple sclerosis, increased risk of hemorrhage (e.g., on anticoagulant medications), impaired thermal regulation, acute inflammation, fever, edema, thrombophlebitis, or acute rheumatoid arthritis -Epilepsy -Cardiovascular or pulmonary disease -Open wounds, catheters, colostomies, IVs, G-tubes -Urinary or fecal incontinence -Certain dermatologic conditions (e.g., ichthyosis, infection) -Venous ulcers -Tissues damaged by radiation therapy -Peripheral vascular disease -Respiratory impairment -More than half-body  immersion during pregnancy

Thermotherapy  contraindications -Decreased circulation -Decreased sensation -Acute/subacute traumatic and inflammatory conditions -Skin infections -Impaired cognition or language barrier -Malignancy -Liniments -Presence of or tendency for hemorrhage or edema -Heat rubs
contraindications precautions: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide and does not replace orders from a physician or the specific protocols of the treatment clinic
electrotherapy contraindications precaut: Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions -Do not place electrodes near: -carotid bodies, cardiac pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators, phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators, phrenic nerve, eyes, gonads -Osteomyelitis -Hemorrhage -Impaired sensation, mental status, communication -Cardiovascular disease -Malignancy -Dermatological conditions -Proximity of electromagnetic radiation -In pregnant women, near the pelvis, lumbar spine, hips, abdomen -In patients with stroke or seizures, near the neck -History of spontaneous abortion in pregnant women

Traction  contraindications/precautions -Spinal trauma -Pregnancy -Suspicion of nonmechanical spine pain -Presence of or potential for joint instability/ligament laxity (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis) -Presence of or potential for bone loss (e.g., osteoporosis, use of steroid medications) -History of spinal surgery or cancer -Claustrophobia -Pulmonary disease
other: Precautions should be taken with the presence of osteoporosis if doing spinal mobilization. Spinal mobilization may also be contraindicated if certain disorders of the spine are present (spondylolisthesis/lysis, vertebral fracture)

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in their assessment and treatment decisions

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Disability and pain Authors of a 2017 systematic review and meta-analysis  concluded that there was a strong relationship between LBP and hypolordosis, especially when compared to age-matched  healthycontrols(25)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Scoliosis Spondylolisthesis Spondylolysis Spondylodiscitis
prognosis: For severe deformity, spinal and other surgical procedures can be effective in normalizing lordosis, with a resulting increase in function and QOL(21)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Orthotist for shoe orthotics Neurosurgeon/orthopedic surgeon for congenital, severe, or rigid deformities. Congenital lordosis is not treated conservatively, as the condition is progressive and can only be treated surgically In cases of severe macromastia with symptoms that have not responded to conservative management, referral to a plastic surgeon to assess appropriateness of breast reduction may be considered
other considerations: Some researchers believe that hypolordosis can lead to chronic LBP(20)  –A 2017 systematic review and meta-analysis  confirmed this association(25)

Authors of a study in Korea identified a greater decrease in lumbar lordosis and lumbosacral angles in subjects who had a posteriorly located center of gravity (COG) compared to subjects with a centrally located COG. The population included 164 patients with LBP. The study suggested that patients with a posteriorly located COG may have more disadvantages in establishing lumbar strength, extension, and static and dynamic balance that affect their ability to maintain postural control(13)

Having the lumbar spine in a position of hyperlordosis during quadruped stabilization exercise in patients with chronic LBP caused more activation of the lumbar multifidus(27) –During quadruped leg raise and quadruped leg-arm  raise exercise, multifidus activity as measured by EMG increased 9.7% and 16.9%, respectively, when compared to neutral posture

Researchers in Switzerland assessed the relationship between heel height and postural changes in women. They found that heel height influences pelvic position when walking. Low-heeled  (4cm) shoes influenced pelvic position less than high-heeled  (10 cm) shoes. This is in contrast to previously published studies(20)

The wearing of high heels by women with experience wearing them was found to not increase lumbar lordosis in static or dynamic conditions but was found to have a small effect of reduced pelvic tilt and a moderate effect of increased pelvic rotation(28) –Based on a German randomized crossover study of 37 younger and middle-aged women experienced with wearing high heels –Static measures (pelvic tilt and lumbar lordosis angle) and dynamic measures (pelvic rotation, median lumbar lordosis angle, and ROM) were measured using a noninvasive back shape reconstruction device (rastersteriography)

Authors of a 2017 systematic review of prospective cohort studies found that the combination of hypolordosis, restriction in lateral flexion of spine, and limited hamstring ROM were associated with increased risk of developing LBP(29) –Based on 12 articles involving 5,459 participants –Meta-analyses  on the following were not significant for LBP: lumbar extension ROM, fingertip-to-floor  flexibility, back extensor strength, back extensor endurance, abdominal strength, quadriceps flexibility, lumbar flexion ROM, and cross-sectional  area of erector spinae and quadratus lumborum
treatment summary: Physical therapy techniques are more likely to be successful when addressing a nonrigid deformity. Restoration of appropriate lumbar lordosis appears to have a positive effect on muscular strength –Authors of a research study found that providing postural cueing to patients while they perform trunk stabilization exercises can improve multifidus muscle activation compared to traditional stabilization exercises alone(19)

Lumbar stabilization exercises are effective for improving functional disability and lumbar lordosis angles in patients with chronic LBP(15) –Thirty patients with chronic low back pain were included in this study in Korea –Subjects were divided equally into the lumbar stabilization exercise group (LSEG) or the conservative treatment group (CTG). The LSEG performed a 5-minute stretching warm-up,  30 minutes of lumbar stabilization exercises, and a 5-minute cooldown. The CTG received a hot pack (20 minutes), interferential current therapy (15 minutes), and ultrasound (5 minutes) –All patients received treatment 3 times/week for 6 weeks –Outcome measures included the ODI and the lumbar lordosis angle measured by plain radiography –ODI scores improved significantly in both groups, with significantly greater improvement in the LSEG. Lumbar lordosis angles increased significantly in the LSEG post treatment, which was significantly better than the CTG post treatment

Based on a study in Turkey, isometric neck extension exercise can improve cervical pain and lordosis(30) –Based on a study of 65 patients with loss of cervical lordosis who were randomly assigned to either a control or intervention group. Both groups received NSAIDs for 10 days. The intervention group was also instructed in a home exercise program of isometric neck extension that they carried out for 3 months –Outcome measures were cervical lordosis angle and neck pain severity at baseline and at 3 months

Authors of a 2019 meta-analysis  concluded that exercise can have a positive effect on kyphosis angle but has no clear effect on lumbar lordotic angle. They also stated that both stretching and strengthening are important for normal lordosis(31) –Ten RCTs were included, with 284 persons with either hypo-  or hyperlordosis and 255 controls. Seven studies examined the kyphosis angle and four studies assessed the lordotic angle

Based on a study in Korea, manipulation based on passive motion analysis is effective for decreasing forward head posture (FHP) and improving cervical lordosis and cervical ROM(16) –Forty university students with impaired cervical posture and ROM were included in this study –Subjects were randomly assigned to one of two manipulation/mobilization groups. The experimental group received a cervical joint manipulation based on passive motion analysis (MBPMA) and the control group received general mobilization –Each group received treatment 3 times/week for 4 weeks, and effects were assessed via radiography –MBPMA was an effective treatment for increasing cervical lordosis and cervical extension ROM, decreasing forward head posture, and improving cervical ranges of flexion and extension motion –Mobilization (control group) was effective in increasing cervical extension ROM and decreasing forward head posture

Authors of a preliminary study in Chile found that continuous use of a mandibular advancement appliance (MAA) in conjunction with a postural reeducation program significantly increased cervical lordosis, thereby improving cervical alignment in patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) and cervical pain with decreased lordosis (< 20°)(17) –MAAs were made for each of the 22 patients. Patients were fitted and seen the first week followed by every 2 weeks for a total of 6 months –A physical therapist evaluated and treated each patient beginning in the third month. Patients received postural reeducation programs to improve alignment of the head and neck and to restore muscular and joint mobility

Pilates exercises improved performance, decreased lumbar lordosis, and decreased pain in patients with chronic non-specific  LBP(18) –Twenty-seven  women with unexplained chronic LBP and hyperlordosis participated in this study in Iran –Patients were randomly assigned to the experimental or control groups. Patients in the experimental group performed 8 weeks of Pilates exercises. The control group did not perform an exercise program –Pre-test/post-test  measures focused on pain level, performance, and the degree of lumbar lordosis and included the Quebec, Oswestry, and Formetric 4D system –The experimental group had a significant improvement in pain, functional mobility, and lumbar lordosis compared to the control group . Improved proprioception and balance–Romberg balance test
Improved gait mechanics and walking speed–Gait assessment

maintenance or prevention: Postural education, ergonomic assessment, targeted strengthening/stretching program
